title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement codeofconduct@posit.co. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to jfbr
text: outlines propose change jfbr. detailed discussion contributing tidyverse packages, please see development contributing guide code review principles.

title: Contributing to jfbr
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to jfbr
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to jfbr
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("jbetz-jhu/jfbr", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to jfbr
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to jfbr
text: Please note jfbr project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Getting help with jfbr
text: Thanks using jfbr! filing issue, places explore pieces put together make process smooth possible.

title: Getting help with jfbr
text: Start making minimal reproducible example using reprex package. haven’t heard used reprex , ’re treat! Seriously, reprex make R-question-asking endeavors easier (pretty incredible ROI five ten minutes ’ll take learn ’s ). additional reprex pointers, check Get help! section tidyverse site.

title: Getting help with jfbr
text: Armed reprex, next step figure ask. ’s question: start community.rstudio.com, /StackOverflow. people answer questions. ’s bug: ’re right place, file issue. ’re sure: let community help figure ! problem bug feature request, can easily return report . opening new issue, sure search issues pull requests make sure bug hasn’t reported /already fixed development version. default, search pre-populated :issue :open. can edit qualifiers (e.g. :pr, :closed) needed. example, ’d simply remove :open search issues repo, open closed.

title: Getting help with jfbr
text: efficient possible, development tidyverse packages tends bursty, shouldn’t worry don’t get immediate response. Typically don’t look repo sufficient quantity issues accumulates, ’s burst intense activity focus efforts. makes development efficient avoids expensive context switching problems, cost taking longer get back . process makes good reprex particularly important might multiple months initial report start working . can’t reproduce bug, can’t fix !

title: Authors and Citation
text: Josh Betz. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Betz J (2024). jfbr: Miscellaneous R Workflow Functions. R package version 0.0.0.9000, https://jbetz-jhu.github.io/jfbr/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {jfbr: Miscellaneous R Workflow Functions},   author = {Josh Betz},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.0.0.9000},   url = {https://jbetz-jhu.github.io/jfbr/}, }

title: Miscellaneous R Workflow Functions
text: jfbr package meant test share miscellaneous functions quantitative workflows.

title: Miscellaneous R Workflow Functions
text: can install development version jfbr GitHub :
code: # install.packages("devtools") # Install devtools if not already installed devtools::install_github("jbetz-jhu/jfbr")

title: Miscellaneous R Workflow Functions
text: Convenience functions added table1::table1() function make easier different summaries add hypothesis testing. package includes example dataset jfbr_test used examples :
code: library(jfbr) library(table1) #>  #> Attaching package: 'table1' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     units, units<- library(knitr) head(jfbr_test) #>   numbers continuous binary ordered binary_factor categorical two_level_group #> 1       1  0.7209039      1       3        1. Yes           1         Group 1 #> 2       2  0.8757732      1       2         0. No           4         Group 2 #> 3       3  0.7609823      0       1        1. Yes           1         Group 1 #> 4       4  0.8861246      1       3        1. Yes           3         Group 1 #> 5       5  0.4564810      1       1         0. No           1         Group 2 #> 6       6  0.1663718      1       4        1. Yes           2         Group 1 #>   three_level_group #> 1           Group 1 #> 2           Group 1 #> 3           Group 3 #> 4           Group 3 #> 5           Group 3 #> 6           Group 1

title: Miscellaneous R Workflow Functions
text: default table1::table1() produce Mean (SD) Median [Min, Max] numeric values, NA treated level factor categorical variables. Note: saving result table1::table1() using knitr::kable()necessary HTML output possible (e.g. output: github_document R Markdown)
code: # table1() defaults my_table <-   table1(     x = ~ continuous + numbers + ordered + binary_factor + categorical |       two_level_group,     data = jfbr_test   )  kable(my_table)

title: Miscellaneous R Workflow Functions
text: Using argument render.continuous = table1_numeric adds Median [IQR] [Max, Min], render.categorical = table1_categorical summarizes observed frequencies tabulates proportion missing values separately: arguments mean_sd, median_iqr, range control summaries computed. Quantiles can added optionally quantiles argment:
code: my_table <-   table1(     x = ~ continuous + numbers | two_level_group,     data = jfbr_test,     render.continuous = table1_numeric,     render.categorical = table1_categorical   )  kable(my_table) # Only Mean/SD my_table <-   table1(     x = ~ continuous + numbers | two_level_group,     data = jfbr_test,     render.continuous =        function(x)         table1_numeric(           x = x,           mean_sd = TRUE, median_iqr = FALSE, range = FALSE,           quantiles = NULL         )   )  kable(my_table) # Only Mean/SD, 5% and 95% Quantiles my_table <-   table1(     x = ~ continuous + numbers | two_level_group,     data = jfbr_test,     render.continuous =        function(x)         table1_numeric(           x = x,           mean_sd = TRUE, median_iqr = FALSE, range = FALSE,           quantiles = c(0.05, 0.95)         )   )  kable(my_table)

title: Miscellaneous R Workflow Functions
text: Hypothesis tests can added table1 using extra.col argument: worked example including t.test chisq.test table1 documentation. table1_pvalue function convenience function allows users supply tests computed table1. defaults include t.test ANOVA omnibus test (via lm anova wrapper) continuous variables, chisq.test categorical variables: function returns element p.value can passed argument, allowing users customize tests performed:
code: my_table <-   table1::table1(     x = ~ numbers + continuous + binary + ordered + binary_factor +       categorical | two_level_group,     data = jfbr_test,     overall = FALSE,     extra.col =       list("p-value" = table1_pvalue)   )  kable(my_table) my_table <-   table1::table1(     x = ~ numbers + continuous + binary + ordered + binary_factor +       categorical | three_level_group,     data = jfbr_test,     overall = FALSE,     extra.col =       list("p-value" = table1_pvalue)   )  kable(my_table) my_table <-   table1::table1(     x = ~ numbers + continuous + binary + ordered + binary_factor +       categorical | two_level_group,     data = jfbr_test,     overall = FALSE,     extra.col =       list("p-value" =              function(x, value) table1_pvalue(                x = x,                variable = variable,                test_numeric_2_levels = wilcox.test,                test_numeric_more_than_2_levels = kruskal.test,                test_categorical_2_levels = fisher.test,                test_categorical_more_than_2_levels = fisher.test              )       )   )  kable(my_table)

what: jfbr: Miscellaneous R Workflow Functions — jfbr-package
title: jfbr: Miscellaneous R Workflow Functions — jfbr-package
text: suite miscellaneous R functions analysis workflow.

title: jfbr: Miscellaneous R Workflow Functions — jfbr-package
text: Maintainer: Josh Betz jbetz@jhu.edu (ORCID)

what: jfbr_test: Example data for testing functions. — jfbr_test
title: jfbr_test: Example data for testing functions. — jfbr_test
text: data.frame containing columns following data types: integer, numeric, 0/1 binary, ordered, factor. column missing value

title: jfbr_test: Example data for testing functions. — jfbr_test
jfbr_test: Example data for testing functions. — jfbr_test
text: data frame 200 rows 8 columns: numbers Participant ID continuous Baseline Covariates 1-4 binary Binary treatment assignment (1 = Treatment; 0 = Control) ordered Outcomes assessments 1-4 binary_factor Time study initiation randomization categorical Study time assessments 1-4 two_level_group Two level factor grouping: missing data three_level_group Three level factor grouping: missing data

title: jfbr_test: Example data for testing functions. — jfbr_test
text: Two grouping variables included missing values, since missing values grouping variables creates error table1::table1().

what: Apply rounding to basic descriptive statistics. — stats_apply_rounding_jfbr
title: Apply rounding to basic descriptive statistics. — stats_apply_rounding_jfbr
text: slight modification table1::stats.apply.rounding. information

title: Apply rounding to basic descriptive statistics. — stats_apply_rounding_jfbr
code: stats_apply_rounding_jfbr(   x,   digits = 3,   digits.pct = 1,   round.median.min.max = TRUE,   round.integers = TRUE,   round5up = TRUE,   rounding.fn = table1::signif_pad,   ... )

title: Apply rounding to basic descriptive statistics. — stats_apply_rounding_jfbr
text: x list, returned stats.default. digits integer specifying number significant digits keep. digits.pct integer specifying number digits decimal place percentages. round.median.min.max rounding applied median, min max? round.integers rounding limited digits right decimal point? round5up numbers 5 last digit always rounded ? standard R approach "go even digit" (IEC 60559 standard, see round), software (e.g. SAS, Excel) always round . rounding.fn function use rounding. Defaults signif_pad. ... arguments.

title: Apply rounding to basic descriptive statistics. — stats_apply_rounding_jfbr
text: list number elements x. rounded values character (numeric) 0 padding ensure consistent number significant digits.

title: Apply rounding to basic descriptive statistics. — stats_apply_rounding_jfbr

Compute some basic descriptive statistics. — stats_jfbr
text: x vector numeric, factor, character, logical values. custom_quantiles vector numeric values (0, 1) quantiles compute quantile_type integer 1 9, passed type argument function stats::quantile() ... arguments (ignored).

what: Compute hypothesis tests for table1::table1() — table1_pvalue
title: Compute hypothesis tests for table1::table1() — table1_pvalue
text: table1::table1() ability add column hypothesis test p-values: see ?table1::table1.

title: Compute hypothesis tests for table1::table1() — table1_pvalue
code: table1_pvalue(   x,   variable,   test_numeric_2_levels = stats::t.test,   test_numeric_more_than_2_levels = function(data, formula) {      data.frame(p.value =     stats::anova(stats::lm(formula = formula, data = data))$`Pr(>F)`[1])  },   test_categorical_2_levels = stats::chisq.test,   test_categorical_more_than_2_levels = stats::chisq.test,   digits = 3 )

title: Compute hypothesis tests for table1::table1() — table1_pvalue
text: x named list values - Typically passed table1::table1(). variable character scalar indicating grouping variable name - Typically passed table1::table1(). test_numeric_2_levels function computes hypothesis test using formula (variable ~ group) group two levels, variable numeric. default t.test, alternatives include: wilcox.test. test_numeric_more_than_2_levels function computes hypothesis test using formula (variable ~ group) group two levels, variable numeric. default omnibus F-test anova(lm(variable ~ group)), alternatives include: kruskal.test. test_categorical_2_levels function computes hypothesis test using formula (variable ~ group) group two levels variable categorical. default chisq.test, alternatives include: fisher.test. test_categorical_more_than_2_levels function computes hypothesis test using formula (variable ~ group) group two levels variable categorical. default chisq.test, alternatives include: fisher.test. digits numeric scalar: number digits use formatting p-values

title: Compute hypothesis tests for table1::table1() — table1_pvalue
text: numeric scalar containing p-value specified hypothesis tests.

title: Compute hypothesis tests for table1::table1() — table1_pvalue
code:
library(table1) data(jfbr_test) table1( x = ~ numbers + continuous + binary + ordered | two_level_group, data = jfbr_test, overall = FALSE, extra.col = list("p-value" = table1_pvalue) ) #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #>
